subject: Re: QS news update
msgSnippet: ... Thanks for finding this. Alas, not only is their tool also based on the CMU dictionary and reflects the PALM=LOT and THOUGHT=CLOTH merger. The Unifon
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Ted Larson Freeman"
<freeman@...> wrote:
>
> Another reference that may be useful is the Unifon dictionary:
> http://www.unifon.org/dictionary.htm
> http://66.41.57.23/UFLookup/UNIFON%20dict.pdf
>

Thanks for finding this. Alas, not only is their tool also based
on the CMU dictionary and reflects the PALM=LOT and THOUGHT=CLOTH
merger. The Unifon alphabet itself only has two letters for
those sounds: it is impossible to represent the RP accent
unambiguously in unifon, you *must* merger those sets to use Unifon.


> I use "Ah," "Awl," and "On," in my personal dictionary, since my
> American Heritage Dictionary makes that distinction. My newer Longman
> dictionary does not. I hope that we who are working on defining lexical
> sets can decide what to do in situations like this. After a while,
> alphabets get defined on how they are used, just as our TO alphabet
did.
> So I want to use QS that is reasonable and readable for everyone.
>

Just wondering: which accent are you trying to recreate?
